justification: The article states that “eye movements are often taken as an indicator of which information a decision maker processes during the decision,” and the Methods section describes recording gaze with webcam-based eye tracking.
construct: Visual attention / information processing during decision-making

measured_by: binary sequential presentation risky choice task (choices between two all-or-nothing gambles)
justification: In the Behavioural task description the authors note that participants "performed a binary sequential presentation risky choice task" where their choices between high-probability/low-amount vs. low-probability/high-amount gambles were recorded to analyse risk preferences.

The Introduction reports that “alternatives that are looked at longer are more likely to be chosen,” treating the relative time an option is viewed as the measure used to capture gaze-based bias in choice.

measured_by: location of the last fixation before choice
justification: The paper notes that “the last fixation before a choice is often directed towards the chosen alternative,” using the last-fixation location as the observable measure of how information order influences choice.
construct: Information order effect / recency bias in choice

measured_by: sequential presentation paradigm manipulating order and duration of attribute displays
justification: The Methods detail an experimental manipulation where attributes were shown in controlled sequences; this sequential presentation paradigm served as the instrument for measuring how attention is allocated to different attributes during choice.
